contextId.information: These words mean basically the same thing. The phrase "a great collapse" defines what the "disaster" will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: disaster ... a great collapse

contextId.information: The words "winnow" and "cleanse" both refer to taking away the bad and leaving the good. AT: "It will not take away their sins." (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It will not winnow or cleanse them

contextId.information: The words "tabernacle" and "tent" share similar meanings. Possible meanings are "my tent and the curtains inside my tent" or "the place where I live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my tabernacle and my tent

contextId.information: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: anger and wrath

contextId.information: The words "brutish" and "stupid" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how foolish the people are for worshiping idols. AT: "Every one of them is very stupid." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: They are all the same, they are brutish and stupid

contextId.information: Both of these words have similar meaning and together emphasize that the servants were ashamed that they were unable to get water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: ashamed and dishonored

contextId.information: The words "wealth" and "treasures" mean the same thing and refer to anything that people consider to be valuable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: wealth and treasures

contextId.information: The words "wealth" and "treasures" mean the same thing and refer to anything that they consider valuable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: all your wealth along with all of your treasures

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people refused to listen. AT: "They refused to listen" or "They refused to obey." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: They did not listen or pay attention

contextId.information: These two expressions basically mean the same thing and emphasize how destructive God's judgment will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: tear it down, or destroy it

contextId.information: These two verbs basically mean the same thing and emphasize God's blessing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: build it up or plant it

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he proclaimed Yahweh's message boldly. AT: "openly proclaimed" or "proclaimed loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: called out and proclaimed

contextId.information: Both of these phrases are idiomatic expressions that refer to great power. AT: "with very great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with a raised hand and a strong arm

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "unrighteousness" and "injustice" have similar meanings and can be stated as actions. AT: "unjustly forced men to build his house and his upper rooms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: builds his house by unrighteousness, his upper rooms by injustice

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: scattering my flock and driving them away

contextId.information: The words "be shattered" mean that someone has caused them to be afraid and mean basically the same thing as "fear." This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one will me them afraid anymore" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they will no longer fear or be shattered

contextId.information: The terms "wicked way" and "corruption of his practices" mean the same thing and refer to every sinful thing that they do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: his wicked way and the corruption of his practices

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is referring to everything that they have done to other nations. AT: "everything that they have done." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: their deeds and the works of their hands

contextId.information: The words "good" and "right" mean the same thing. AT: "Do to me whatever you think is the right thing to do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Do to me what is good and right in your eyes.

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will respond to their prayers. AT: "pray to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: call to me ... pray to me

contextId.information: The words "hissed words" refer to a sound of strong disapproval that people make when they say bad things about others. The phrase has basically the same meaning as "curses." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: curses and hissed words

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "conduct" and "deeds," which are similar in meaning, can be translated as verbs. AT: "and will reward everyone according to how good or evil the things they do are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: to give to each man what his conduct and deeds deserve

contextId.information: The words "wrath" and "fury" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how very angry he is. AT: "the people of Jerusalem have made me very angry since the day they built their city." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: this city has been a provocation of my wrath and fury since the day that they built it.

contextId.information: All three words mean the same thing and emphasize how very angry he is. AT: "extreme anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: wrath, fury, and great anger

contextId.information: The words "wrath" and "fury" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his wrath. AT: "in my extreme wrath." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: in my wrath and fury

contextId.information: These words share similar meanings in this context. They describe Yahweh as a witness whom no one will be able to contradict. AT: "trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: true and faithful

contextId.information: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:33:14|33:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: In those days and at that time

contextId.information: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:33:14|33:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: In those days and at that time
